text: Bottle from Sprouts: Poured a dark brown liquid and was topped with a fluffy foam cap head. Aroma is decked with scents of fresh hop that bring on notes of citrus fruit peel, onion and a touch of rye bread. Very subtle drinking beer that only after swallowing does the flavor become more apparent. Taste is slightly bitter but brings about sweetness from the strong backbone of dark malts added.

Deep dark brown coloured body with a thick tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, alcohol, deep hops, earth, caramel and a hint of molasses. Medium to Full-bodied; Deep robust earthy malt with a lot of caramelised sugars, some pungent earthy and floral hops and a big bite of alcohol. Aftertaste shows the decently balanced malt and hops with a bit too much bitterness, some assertive alcohol and roasted malt and a touch of grain and lactose on the finish. Overall, a decent Imperial Black IPA, with nothing making this great nor a must sample. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Fair Lakes (Fairfax), Virginia on 04-February-2016 for US$9,99 sampled at home in Upstate New York (New Paltz) on 22-July-2016. 

Brewed on: 09-Jan-2016 // Enjoy By 24-Feb-2016 // Purchased on 04-Feb-2016 // Sampled: 22-July-2016
Version 04.20.16. String and very thick. With the Stone brewing signature in all its features. Quite complicated these versions.

Olmost black with an off white head - Hop aroma with some malt in the back - Malt body to support a good hop profile that has some hints of pine and a good bitterness - The pine and bitterness goes into the finish - This was good

Tap at Stone Oceanside. Version 11.27.15. Clear deep brown pour with thick tan foam. Sticky lace. Nose is a bit funky like grilled durian, grapefruit, charred fruit, and mint. Taste is nicely bitter, not over the top, with grilled fruit and grapefruit bitterness taking center stage. I think its safe to say that Stone knows how to make this style by now and this version doesnt disappoint.
Tap @ Postbellum. I love black IPAs and this didnt disappoint. Tried a couple other beers that day but came back to this one. yummy.

With an Enjoy By date of 5.4.16, today was a very appropriate day to crack open the blackened version of Stones much-loved Enjoy By IPA. Given Stones emphasis on this sort of thing, its fair to guess this was the freshest Black IPA Ive tasted. I know it was the most beautiful. Black body and a tight head that sparkles. Im not trying to be hyperbolic or cute. The foam really does glisten. Aromas of roasted malt, woodsy pine, herbal tobacco, zesty citrus, and a hint of smoke. Bright, juicy grapefruit flavors with sappy pine needles and subtler touches of cocoa, caramel, and coffee. Texture is oily and somewhat thick. For what can be a pretty aggressive style, Enjoy By Black is relatively mellow. Lovely.
On tap at Schatzis. Pours a clear cola brown. Soft roast, citrus and mango onion. Medium bodied, roast, chocolate, onion and mango. Warm alcohol into the finish, esters, grapefruit, roast.

Bottle 05.04.16 from Stone Brewery place next to Petco stadium, San Diego - black with a thick beige head. Aroma of citrusy hops, pine, roasted malts. A lot of grapefruit in the taste with pine, coffee, roasted malts, chocolate. Lovely smooth mouthfeel, low carbonation, nice pithy, malty bitter finish. Should have bought more than one of these.
Aroma is a complex mix of dank hops, spices and dark malts. The flavor is orange/fruit, dark malts, citrusy hops, spices and a mix of mild heat and bitter in the finish.

Enjoy by 5/4/16 Edition. Bomber from Nob Hill in Monterey Ca, for $7.49. Dark brown and reddish pour with with a half inch thick tan head that lasts. Aroma is an impressively strong and pleasant ruby red grapefruit. Flavor is ruby red grapefruit, some tropical fruit, and pithy bitterness. This is a good beer, though I like Self Righteous a little better because of its better integration of roasted malts into the flavor of the beer.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, piney hops, citrus and grapefruit. Flavor of dark roasted malts, coffee, citrus, piney hops, soft caramel, light chocolate and had some notes of tropical fruit with a bitter lingering roasty finish.

Dark brown color with light brown, creamy head. Aims is really hoppy with dank, earthy, resiny notes. Taste starts slightly sweet and roasty, hoppy with with earthy and piney notes, finishes bitter and roasty. Body is heavy and well carbonated. A good example of west coast style black DIPA.
On tap at belmont station. Pours a clear black color with a medium white head. A big fruity fresh ashy citrus nose. The flavor is chocolate, ash, citrus, oranges, light bitterness. Quite good.
Bomber->tulip/snifter. Dark brown with thick frothy lite tan head. A: pine hops, roasted malt. T: roasted malt, chocolate, bitter pine hops. Musky. Really good.

On tap at Birch Hill before the enjoy by date. Poured into a tulip. Dark brown with a nice khaki head. Aroma of anise, roasted malts, sugar, and resin. Taste is way too much black licorice and sugar, very oddly balanced with the hops. Medium body, the 2/14/16 version is way overrated.

One of the five (!) beers that Matt bought back from San Diego. Very dark ruby-brown, light beige sudsy head. Smells of moderate roast malt, heavy toasty, dusty hop. Tastes of roast malt, somewhat acidic coffee, heavy stony bitterness, mildly burnt and lemony finish. Body is very smooth, a bit chewy, slightly sharp then becomes stony and bitter. Less dark than most black IPAs, but plenty of bitterness and a lightly coffee roastiness. Had this 3 weeks after its Enjoy By date but didn't taste unfresh. Very nice.

Best before 2.14.16 drank nearly 3 weeks after. Oh well. Bottle from SD at home in HK. Dark cola brown-black pour with thick slightly tan (off white) head. Aroma is big pine resin hops with a little bit of roasted coffee grounds, but much more hop-forward. Still really enticing. Taste is big resiny bitterness with a lot of alcohol too. The roasted flavors of a black IPA only come at the end, with a bit more coffee and then lasting bitter resin and booze. Had lowered my expectations based on other reviews but this is delicious, even if less roasted than expected for a black IPA.

Bomber. Grapefruit hop aroma with pine resiny hop notes and only a little bit of roast. Pours black with a large tan head with excellent retention but poor lacing. Starts with grape fruit hops as well as a bit of roast. Finishes dry with grapefruit citrus and acidity as well as strong bitter pine resiny hops. Not bad, but not a lot of roast contrast for a black IPA. Will try again next iteration.

Split a 22 of the 2/14/2016 bottling, had 12 days "after the date" - ah well. Poured a dark brown color, with a tan head. Aroma was lots of earthy, roasted, resin notes. Flavor was resin, lots of roast, chewy hops, chewy malts. Okay ,but missing something. I know I had it "late" but 12 days shouldnt make or break a beer. Not as good as I remember their 11th Anniversary.
Cloudy brown thin rimming Lacy beige head aroma is mildly hoppy floral; flava is hoppy spicy bitter; feels medium and chalky moderate fizz; finishes hoppy dry bitter

Enjoy by 02.14.16 and consumed on 01.22.16. The 22oz bomber pours up with a dark mahogany colored body that has some deep infrared hues and supports a tan head of foam. The aroma offers up tangelo, grapefruit and almost candy like sweet clementine as well as thin slivers of dark roasted malts and chocolate malts. The taste delivers rich dark roasted malts surrounded by a sea of bitter and slightly juicy grapefruit and tangerine like citrus hoppiness. The dark roasted malts take on a thin soft chocolate edge to midway before giving way to a growing bitter to near resiny hoppiness heading into the finish. Solid.
Dark brown pour under a nice tan head. Nice aroma, bold fresh hoppiness, pine, citrus, dank, light coffee and roasted malts. Great flavor, nicely hoppy, fresh hops, dank, roasted malts. Tasty!

Thanks to Maxbier for sharing. Pours black with an tan head. Aroma is tropical fruit. Flavor is tropical fruit and citrus with a slight roasted malt finish. Very little bitterness. Fantastic Black IPA.

Pours a clear brownish black on tap with fluffy tan head that dissipates slowly to leave good lace. Aroma of piney hops with a nice roasty middle. Taste follows, clean and simple, nice moderate bitterness that lingers. Really nice black IPA.

Bomber. Didnt know this existed but happy to investigate. Roasty chocolate malts and some citrus and pine. Definitely exactly what you would thinkit would be. Heavily hopped and citrusy like the original with some chocolate and smoke flavors.
bottled as 2/14/16 on 2/13, right at the buzzer. - Poured black, really fresh hops as promised, roasted malts and some mpiney hops. Really good - woud drink again
Bomber bottle. Dark brown in color with an off white head. Pine, floral, some earthiness, anise, and a bit of roastiness.

Pours deep, warm coffee sable with a thick and rather persistent buff head. Just a bit of daylight peeps through at the bottom. Damn, the gnats that have been plaguing me like paparazzi love this, too! No wonder, since the hoppy, woody aroma reaches out and touches you from half a meter away. Closer in, you capture roast malt and licorice tones. Formidable flavor presents woody hop, hay, roast malt, coffee, toffee and licorice tones. A deep, dark wonder indeed - I really love black IPAs. Mouthfeel features firm body, plenty of fizz, and a hoppy and roast malt/coffee finish. Im enjoying the 2/14/16 version on 2/15/16, but hey, I tend to be fashionably late.

650ml bottle from Cork in Rockford. On the final freshness date! For my 100th black ipa - such an interesting style, and when done well, can be excellent. Black pour with a beige head. Some streaky lace. Aroma has citrus and pine and black malts. Taste is of grapefruit, salty tangy black malts, some roast, some chewy resin and a touch of soy. Blend is very well done. Medium bodied. A bit lowly carbonated with almost no alcohol presence. Finishes more bitter than bittersweet. Roasty, tangy. A very good example for style - no surprise from Stone, and especially fresh Stone. 14.8

22 ounce bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 1/9/2016. Pours fairly clear very dark brown color with a 2 finger dense and rocky light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big tangerine, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, papaya, passion fruit, mango, melon, berry, lemon zest, orange peel, light pepper, pine, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted bread, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome complexity and balance of juicy citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate roasted malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big tangerine, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, papaya, passion fruit, mango, melon, berry, lemon zest, orange peel, light pepper, pine, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted bread, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Moderate amount of pine/citrus rind/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of tangerine, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, papaya, passion fruit, mango, melon, berry, lemon/orange peel, pine, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted bread, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of juicy citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate roasted malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero astringent hop flavors after the finish. Moderate dryness from bitterness that increases through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, sticky, and lightly creamy/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warmth lingering after the finish. Overall this is a fantastic Black DIPA! All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of juicy citrus/tropical/piney hops and moderate roasted malt flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle. Pours a near black color with a moderate light tan head on there. Nose is floral and resiny and hop forward, without much roasting. Taste is bitter and roasty and super fresh. Very light and satisfying brew.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a deep ruby red color with a thick tan head that settles to a film and lasts to the end leaving some lacing. Aroma is a nice fresh citrus hop aroma with caramel and roasted malt. Medium full body with a slight stickiness to it. Taste is well balanced between the hops and malt. Slight dry roasted finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bomber on the final enjoy by date of 02.14.16. Pours boot black with a light finely foamed tan head. Aroma is floral hops and mild citrus fruit. A touch of malt. Taste is roasted malts and piney hops with some mild citrus notes that resolve into a bitter backend. Balanced fuity-roasty aftertaste. Active mouthfeel. Very good.

Dark brown color. Thick, tan, creamy head that falls into a very nice lacey ring. Fresh hop aroma. Banana, ginger, nuts, lemon and cherries also define the aroma. Slight bitterness. Sticky mouthfeel. Long hoppy finish. Average carbonation. Meduim bodied. Taste honey, salt, and a hint of fresh cilantro. This was awesome beer. Great job Stone. Keeping me as a repeat customer.

Bottle. Black pour with a tall, fluffy tan head. Big floral and resinous hops up front with soft fruit and light roasted malt. Taste is big oily hops, floral hops, roasted malt, caramel and tropical fruit notes. Body is medium-full and chewy with a dense, creamy carbonation. Lingering hop bitterness to this as well. Ends with more roasted malt, chocolate covered oranges, floral hops, pine and tropical fruit.

On tap @ University of Beer - Sacramento. Black beer with a finger of tan foam. Dank. Really reminds me a lot of the original Stone 11th Anniversary/Sublimely Self Rigtheous, but maybe less bitter and more citrus forward. Tons of pineapple, grapefruit, and orange. Certainly has some roasted malts and bitter pine, but very fruit driven. Solid stuff. One of the better stone beers in awhile.
Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown. Aroma and flavor are rich earthy and roasted bitterness with some dark chocolate and very faint floral notes. Medium body.

Aroma is predominantly pine, pours a clear, dark ruby red with a huge off-white head. Very nice interplay between roast and pine/tropical fruit notes. Theres a hint of licorice that comes through as well. Lingering bitter finish, playing well with the roast. Moderate mouthfeel, and a well hidden 9.4% ABV makes this a great Black IPA.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber.
This is a solid beer, Stone always delivers.
I do not care for the roasted malt character with the citrusy and pine of the hops. There are some chocolate notes that are pleasant. If black IPAs are your thing then this is for you.
Tap. Black with one finger head. Huge hops, much like the regular Enjoy By. Chocolate and coffee, roasty malt. Strong piney bitterness. Reminds me of self righteous for obvious reasons.

Bottle, Enjoy by 2.14.16. Tis indeed black, with a nice frothy top of sturdy foam. This has a nice westie aroma. And for a guy who normally doesnt like so-called "black IPAs" this has a wonderful first impression, with a nice fruity nose and initial citric appeal. Then the aspects of black IPAs that I dont like creeps in ... that chalky aspect that might contribute to a nice porter. But it doesnt settle well with that hoppy pile. Im not a fan of the style, but this is one of the better bad examples. :-) (#6115, 2/9/2016)

28/I/16 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle @ ElMananas place - BB: II/14/16 (2016-78) Thanks to Steve for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark red brown beer, creamy beige irregular head, pretty stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: bit cheesy, dank, smelly, some malts, little roasted. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: bit grassy, green hops, little citrus, fruity, sweet, caramel, hops. Aftertaste: grassy hops, soft roast, little fruity, grapefruit, very bitter, dry. Pretty nice stuff.
Draft at Meridian Pint. Clear maroon brown color, beige head. Aroma of pine and cocoa. Taste has bitter burnt espesso and bitter cocoa with bitter pine. Pretty bitter.

Tap; Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of fresh pine hops, chocolate, coffee, & some citrus; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, dark chocolate, pine hops, coffee, and citrus; Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced; Good stuff.

Bomber from Whole Foods Charlottesville. 02.14.16 vintage. Dark brown, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, piney hops. The taste is intensely dark roasted malt, soy, coffee, piney and resin hops. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness.

Bottle, black beer, big almond colored head, good lace. Aroma toasty barley, wet dog and metal. Taste is toasted barley, spruce, citrus rind, sweet malt, metal, and yes a hint of wet dog? Not the best black IPA Ive ever had. Palate is fairly rich, carbonation subdued.

Nose if fruity - tropical and grapefruit with some pine and dank. Caramel and medium roast, floral finish. Black pour tan head. Flavors of danky tropical hops chewy resins on top of medium roast soft caramel sweetness. Roast becomes more prevalent in the finish. Danky dry finish. Good take on a style that isn't my favorite.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2016 Good. Rye bread flavor prevails at end. Leads with caramel and yeast. A little thick but a great black ipa.  Hints of plums and citrus

Picked up a growler of the 2-14-16 vintage. I always look forward to the Enjoy By beers. This pours a a very dark brown with light tan head and nice lacing. Aroma reminds me a little of the unfiltered IIPA with a certain dankness but with more of a dark malt presence and the pine seems more pronounced. As it warmed a I also noticed a little citrus as well. Taste is bitter, with pine dominating along with some citrus and earthiness. I do not notice much in the way of roast. Medium bodied. The alcohol is hidden very well. Decent but I preferred Sublimely Self Righteous.

22 oz bottle, 2-14-16 edition- Pours dark cola brown to almost black with a light mocha tan head that retains nicely leaving cobwebby lace. Aroma is pungent hops, citrus, dank and sticky, roasted grains, near perfect balance. The taste is excellent as well, nice balance of caramel and chocolate malts and the sticky pungent hops, very velvety and smooth, creamy. I have lost interest in this style, but am starting to remember why i originally loved it.

2-14-16 vintage bottle. Poured black/brown color with a fluffy off-white head. Aroma was nice and reminded me of older versions of Enjoy By with a heavy pine, citrus, onion, and a dankness. Flavor was pine, grapefruit, onion, heavy amounts of booze is where it went wrong. The past 4 or 5 beer in the Enjoy By series have all been this way so either my tastes have changed 100% or this beer isnt what it once was. Full body, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and heavy booze and alcohol burn to finish.

bottle, shared by Eric. Pour is pitch black with a beige-white head. Aroma has pungest blast of piney, resinous hops layered with roasts and coffee. Body is creamy but not heavy, with moderate effervescence. Flavor crescendos nicely with pine, citrus, dank hops married with roasts and smoky malts that are never chalky and overly tannic. Really beautiful, balanced stuff, top of the category for black IPA.
22 ounce bottle. Pine and grapefruit and bitterness and hoppy notes followed by some roast and chocolate. Nice.
2/14/16 vintage. Shared in basement witth buddy alex. A strongly hopped body dark malts support. Nose is luscious. Body floats a dark mocha head. Yummy.

Bottle 02.14.16. Deep brown color with a persistent brown head lots of thick soapy lacing. Nose is full of pine and citrus hops, roast. Tastes mostly roast and moderate in bitters. Lingering piney finish. Something in there that Id associate with spruce gets a little distracting, but overall a pretty solid CDA.

Bomber into snifter glass, deep-ruby darker brown color with light tan head. Aroma notes of heavy pine, citrus, roasted malt, grapefruit, grass, some chocolate and tad earthy. Taste seems sweeter than aroma; caramel, more chocolate, some smoke, light tropical fruits and more herbal hop bitterness. Medium-heavy body, moderate carbonation, dry, creamy with lingering heavy pine/citrus bitterness. Excellent black IPA.

Bomber. Enjoy By 2.14.16. Aroma is extremely piney backed by some roastiness, earthiness, root beer barrels, toasted marshmallow. Pours black with a thick beige head with excellent retention and lots of splotchy lava lamp lace; ruby red highlights appear when held up to the light. Taste is medium-level bitter* backed by some candy sweetness; its roasty with lots of citrus and pine notes.The best dark hoppy beer Ive had since Gigantics Slip Into Darkness, but maybe its the only dark hoppy beer Ive had since then. Ha ha. I dont drink this style all that often anymore.

*After half a glass, that "medium-level bitter" lingers and builds on the tongue long after the swallow. Its accumulative bitterness for sure.

Pours coffee-brown with average head and lace. The aroma is pine, citrus, dark roasted malt, bitter bread (something close to rye). More bitterness on the front of the flavor, and another rush on the back, plus that charcoal, smokey, roasted malt character. Not as good as the damn-near perfect regular version of Enjoy By, and probably not as good as Sublimely Self Righteous. But still a very good black IPA.

Enjoy By 2.14.2016. Aroma is much like the original, tons of tropical fruit, slight booze, slight roasted malt, pine. Appearance is dark dark brown, light tan head. Taste is very robust, lots of roasted malt, coffee, layered with nice tropical fruit, lots of pine, slight booze. Mouthfeel is medium body, light but crisp carbonation. Overall, the original is better to me but this is a very well done black IPA.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate grapefruit, citrus, light pine, dank hops, chocolate, and barely some roast. It pours a a dark brown with some reddish-orange transparency when held to the light. It has a large tan head that eventually settles to a thin film outlined by a thick ring. There is some thin soapy webbing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with a quick dose of light-moderate chocolate. The finish has moderate-heavy grapefruit, lighter pine, light dank hops, and a touch of roast. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2016 The nose features some dank hops, fresh pink grapefruit and a hint of chocolate. A near black body with an ample, thick, off-white head. Grapefruit, rindy and grassy hops are there from the outset, really well integrated with slightly roasted malt, caramel, a touch of chocolate and some creaminess. There is a rumour of mint and other spices underneath the lead tastes. Strong effervescence, a solid body and a clean finish show the craft of this pretty understated Stone product.
Looks and smells better than it tastes. Its not overly roasted but its just not as good as the other enjoy beers.

22oz bottle with a bottled on date of 1/09/16 - 21 days old.

Very easy drinking 9% beer. Lots of carbonation.

Not as impressed as the original Enjoy By, but still a very good Black IPA

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2016 Aroma: roasty, pine, resin, citrus, earthy, 
Appearance: dark brown with a tan head
Taste: light sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter finish,

Delicious
Bottle at home, brought by Steve, thanks alot! 02/14/2016 date. Very spicy, herbal, dry, does this have anything in common with the regular Enjoy By? I like it, but Self Righteous was much better.
Draft. Happy and sweet chocolate aroma. Dark midnight body. Flavor is grassy hops with a malty body. Smooth and quenching.

Bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, pine resin, grapefruit zest and light cocoa. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth dry finish. Flavors of roasted malt, cocoa, pine and light grapefruit zest with a smooth dry bitter lingering roasty pine finish.

22 oz bomber, Enjoy by 02/14/16, Bottled 01/09/16, served 1/27/16. Dark reddish brown, tight tan head, excellent retention, sticky rings of lace. Aroma is dank, piney, citrusy hops, dark toasty bread. Flavor starts sweet, roasty malt, coffee, maybe some light chocolate. Then the hops come in. Juicy citrus, grapefruit, pine, herbal.  Well hidden alcohol, and a lingering bitter finish.

12/26/15. Bottle thanks to cbfobes, I believe. Dark brown pour under a nice tan head. Nice aroma, bold fresh hoppiness, pine, citrus, dank, light coffee and roasted malts. Great flavor, nicely hoppy, fresh hops, dank, roasted malts. Tasty!
Some roast and some citrus. Pours black with great head and lacing. Some creamy consistency. Light bitter finish. Good balance. Tap at churchkey.

Draft at Slows GR - pours a dark brown with light tan head . Piney hop aroma with faint roast . Super fresh hop flavor . Solid offering . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap Sedona. Enjoy by 2/14/16. Outstanding aroma
Of grapefruit and pine. Taste is a delicious blend of pine, citrus peel, oranges pulp, flowers, burnt malts. Delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at ABV Public House in Hillsboro, OR. Roasted malt aroma and taste. Just enough sweetness to take the edge off the hops. Medium mouthfeel. Nice to see Stone expanding the Enjoy By brand. Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2016 Black with ruby highlights. Smell is wonderful. Big clean juicy tropical fruit. Classic Stone west coast hop flavor but you do get some roastyness and chocolate on the back and in the aftertaste.
Draft at Bricks. Pours black with some tan head. Nose is lots of regular Enjoy By. Taste adds some roast. Good.
Bottle from Final Gravity. Pours dark brown with a clinging tan head and a strong pine aroma. There is a full-bodied treacle and anise flavor with a very bitter pine finish.

Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours ruddy dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is rather piney over some lightly burnt malt. Med + body. Flavor is slightly malty with a lot of pine hop. Not harsh, but close enough - sight hop burn. Finishes somewhat less than dry, but pretty hoppy.

Deep ruby red pour, almost black under a single finger tan head. Bright citrus aroma, orange zest specifically and a some caramel on the nose. Medium bodied. Really strong at first, a lot going on. Dry finish, but its also juicy. Super juicy ruby red grapefruit, caramel and roasted grain. A little astringent. Lace present. As always, Stone knows how to do a hoppy beer.

This beer was so awesome to review. Its super interesting and ended up being incredible. Im not the biggest fan of black ipas. Most of the ones Ive had end up being more malt and roast forward and miss out on big pungent hoppiness. I love that this beer smelled like a fresh squeezed grapefruit and looks like a stout. Its weird in a cool way. The aroma is super aromatic with big grapefruit and dankness. Super fresh which is what makes it so good. Taste is like a big grapefruit with subtle roasted undertones. I think what makes it work so well is the big sweet roasted malts cut by the massive hops. And the right hops at that. The perfect combo of hops made this beer what it was, which I think makes a huge difference in black ipas. Overall its excellent and looks like it should be big and chewy and its a citrus bomb. I loved it and highly recommend getting it before its no longer available.

Black mahogony with wispy white head. Aroma is dank cat piss. Complex roast chocolate.Big pine. Real hoppy. Taste is rich smooth fairly dry soft. Sweet but bitter. Chocolate light roast. Hoppy pine. Nice.

22oz bottle pours a translucent deep brown with some lacing, creamy white head. Nose is pretty cool, theres a great tropical fruit hop thing happening, a little chive and cream, a little chocolate, even a little white chocolate. Flavor is really nice, guava and mango, some grass, light bread, some brown sugar. A nice bitterness from the roast comes through on the end. Most black IPAs go too strong on the roasted malt. This is the perfect balance. Dry, fruity finish.

Born on date 1/9/2016. Bottle from super deli. After opening a rather large milky head appears. Is lactose used in this? Pours a really dark brown. Malts are nice but not overly malty but does have a good backbone to support the hops. Great beer would have another.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark, cola-brown/black with good-sized, cream head (looks almost like a glass of Guinness stout). Strong, dank, floral hop aroma. Flavor is full of hop bite, with roasted grain, licorice, nuttiness. Pretty darn good.

22 oz bottle (Enjoy By 02.14.16 Black IPA) poured into a Bruery tulip. Black with two fingers of beige head. Nice lacing. Aromas of grapefruit and orange citrus, floral notes, light bitter roasty notes, subtle cocoa. Tastes of floral notes, pine, grapefruit citrus, roasty notes, a little bit of garlic and onion. Medium body with a dry and slightly warm finish. Pretty good.

22oz bomber 13 days old. Pours a deep brown with beige head and good lacing. Aroma is good with piney hops and moderate roasted malts. Taste is flavorful throughout - first with a sweet roasted malt up front, quickly relieved by the original Enjoy By hops coming through to keep the balance on the hop side of the scale. Its good, but not nearly as stellar as the Double IPA version. Wouldnt pay for a bomber of this one again, as nice as it was.

Near black body with a huge, soapy, tan head. Strong aroma of pine, resinous hops, chocolate malt. Hop forward, robust body, moderate bitterness throughout. Bold flavor and a pleasant beer to drink. Solid.

Disappointing. Aroma sorta like normal enjoy by but the taste to me was like an old out of date enjoy by. Not a winner from stone. Their Enjoy By is works class, this one is a failed derivative. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle pours very dark brown with 1.5 finger white head. Nose is big pine, grassy, light roast, vanilla, melon, citrus. Taste has soft roast, dark coffee bean, bitter piney grass, citrus, herb. Finishes bitter, sticky pine, cocoa, coffee, roast, chickory, grassy melon. Great black ipa.
On tap at bier thirty pours out cola color topped with a tan head. nose is big dank hops citrus some roast malts. Taste more of the big hop combo and a light roast along with a malty sweetness.

I drank this 16 days after the date of expiration, so feel free to discount my opinion. This pours to a deep black, no hints of color. Big off white head thats thick and retains. Smell is a mix of IPA hoppiness and pine with a more roasty brown ale smell in there as well. Slight aroma of floral. Taste is the same clash. Big hops and bitter qualities with a stout, coffee like presence as well. Quite well balanced

Bomber. Clear dark brown with a foamy, thick, tan head that lasts and laces. Aromas of grapefruit, pine, melon, light roasted malt and coco. Flavor is grapefruit, pine, roasted malt, light peach, melon, and cocoa.Medium bodied, smooth with a bitter, roasty finish.

Bottle. Kind of a light brown to black pour with an off white head. Aroma of hops and smoke with a touch of pine. Taste is pine hops with roastiness. Mouthfeeel a little thin imo. Overall, a very good brew.

bottle, from the Beer Dispensary Apex. 02/14/16 edition. good aroma, sweet. pine smokey roasty. dark orangy brown color, ok head and laceBitter sweet flavor. medium body, light creamy mouthfeel, Btter finish. a classic zblack spa. linguring bitterness on finish, on the pine side of thing in botharoma and finish.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: On tap @ Stone OSide. Black pour with a scattering of dark tan foam. Aroma is pungent/resinous pine and stark bitterness with slight roast. Taste is heavily bitter, piney, and with some underlying roast/chocolate. Chewy mouthfeel. Nice in small doses.

Bottle. Pours clear mahogany, medium tan head, great lacing. Aroma is pine, grapefruit, roasty malts. Flavor follows, light plus sweet, medium bitter. Medium body. My failure to enjoy by perhaps muted this one a bit, but its still tasty.

Bottle. Aroma is a mix of ultra dank hops and dusty cocoa. Tastes moderately sweet with huge dank hops. Tropical fruit, pine, cocoa, burnt wood and weed. Super oily. So over the top but I enjoyed this.

Black IPA.   
つよいホッピ&
Pours a cola black with ruby highlights. Thick off-white head with lots of lacing. Hoppy aroma. Bitterness throughout. A bit of burnt grain.

Enjoy by 1/1/16 version. Wow. Straight out of the gate this is a crazy, all over the place beer. The hops blast out of the glass but theres catty, earthy, peppery, piney.... You cant tell whats coming next. The one thing that is clear is that this is a very fresh beer. Even though I broke the rules and waited until after the enjoy by date, this is still hella fresh. Although this looks black in a big glass, its actually just barely a crystal clear dark brown topped with a very light tan head. Expecting a blast of bitterness, I get exactly what I expect, except that its incredibly well balanced. Theres pretty much all of the hop aromas in the taste and its all spicy bitter goodness. Just when its about to overwhelm, the dark roasted malt kicks in with milk and dark chocolate and maybe a touch of molasses. The sweetness that comes with this does an admirable job of balancing the bitter onslaught, but in the end the hops win. The alcohol comes around the back to blast all that bitterness home. In the end, its a bitter, chocolaty hot mess. And I love it.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a black with a slight ruby tinge in light. Aroma is citrus fruit with some chocolate and a slight hint of coffee. Taste is moderate to heavily bitter with a nice malt backbone. Flavors of grapefruit, chocolate, coffee, caramel. Overall a very well done black ipa. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Enjoy by 1/1/16 enjoyed 12/31/15 in a snifter.

Look - Dark brown body. Finger of light tan head settles to a ring. Bubbles are large. Lacing is good.

Smell - Enjoy by musty. Even a blind smell picks up chocolate.

Taste - Chocolate. Bitter coffee. Grapefruit. Must.

Feel - Dry. Tongue ripper.

Overall - It has been a while since I had a musty shower smell - taste. Faint coffee and chocolate. I like this.

Bottle. Enjoyed on expiration date. Malts do a nice job on a really hoppy IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber, enjoy by 01/01/2016. Its 12/31/2015, so perhaps not in its prime, but I also dont quite buy the "Enjoy By" marketing bit of having it at its best by a certain date. Not a typical black IPA for me. A smattering of roasty malt, but not as much as it should have. Some coffee, some dark chocolate and weirdly, anise. Nice hops bitterness though. Im not impressed, but it sounds like my bottle is atypical.
Pours black into a snifter. Mocha head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Sour caramel aromas. Dark chocolate covered pit fruit and sour cocoa front to back.

Dark copper. 
Full body, dense and assertive flavor, well hidden alcohol, lingering palate. 
Bitter, crisp, off-dry. 
Roast and hoppy flavors. 
Accomplished example of the style, refreshing, enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bottle("enjoy by 1/1/16", bottled 11/25/15) pours an opaque dark brown with lasting beige head and good lacing. Aroma is full of pine resin and dank fruity hops. Taste is quite bitter with the roasted malts and a bit of cocoa coming out only in the aftertaste. Body is medium with average carbonation and a slightly sticky mouthfeel with no alcohol burn, despite the 9.4%. Ive enjoyed several excellent Stone "Enjoy By" IPAs but this one is quite different: more bitter, quite dank, lacking caramel malts, and with a touch of dark fruit and roasted malts. This is a great Black IIPA which I would rate even higher if it werent so dank. Stone never disappoints, and this is an unclassifiable one (Imperial Porter? The black sheep of their DIPA family?) Well worth checking out.

Bottle from Table and Vine. Dark brown with lasting head and lace. Citrus caramel brownies aroma. Burnt caramel roasted coffee chocolate raisin sweetness with citrus and woody pine bitterness. Full body creamy. I would have preffered a regular 6.5% BIPA. Still very good. But very close to an imperial hoppy porter.
650ml bottle. Black/brown pour. Nearly 0% roasted malt character, instead quite acidic and a medium bitterness, not the greatest black ipa, but fresh.
Bottle from Gentiles. Poured black with off white head. Aroma of tomato pasta sauce malt. Light carb med bod. Taste roasted malt resin quite bitter.

Dark brown pour with a three finger fluffy off white head. Aroma is big on floral, fruity, dense citrus, dank and resinous hops, a little breadiness, toast and chocolate coming through as well. Flavor is big citrus, spruce tips and tropical fruit, some fruit blossoms, a little earthiness, light roast and a hint of bitter sweet chocolate. Light to medium body, creamy and chewy to slightly chalky feel, light to medium, somewhat sharp carbonation. Really good stuff overall, metric tons of hops.

Thin looking brown pour with a small tan head. Aromas of juicy tropical fruit and some pine. Taste is bitter and on the dry side. Flavors of citrus hop goodness...excellent hop expression. Very fruity. I really like this beer.
Extremely well-done. This is Black IPA perfected. Extremely well-balanced and hops linger. Stone continues to develop yet define.

This should be 99-100 in style eventually. HUGE resin and fruit nose. The black part actually takes a bit to come out, but eventually does so nicely. Near ruinous hop head heaven flavor, with a little chocolate and dark roast to "balance". Chewy feel. Will revisit, but Im pretty sure Stone has made my top 4 Black IPAs of all-time...15, Loland BA 15, SSR, and this.

Bomber to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Enjoy By 01.01.16. Looks good; a translucent very dark cola with foamy light beige head. Smells of dark malt, dark chocolate, and roast alongside notes of bitter and piney hops. A bit of citrus zest as well. Mouthfeel is medium full-bodied and pleasantly bitter. Good beer.

Pour dark brown-black with a one finger tan head with a nice lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, tropical fruits, coco, coffee, sweet malts, and lightly roasted malts. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a semi-creamy mouthfeel and a moderately bitter, semi dry, long, lingering finish. Overall, a tasty, hoppy, yet still somewhat well balanced black IPA.

Dark brown pour with a light khaki head. Aroma of pine, light cocoa and orange. Taste is orange rond, pine, roast is very light, finishes bitter and some traces of cacao, very good, but I would like to see a bit more of a toasty presence, not a shit ton, but enough to set this apart from a DIPA.

Pours a deep dark ruby color when held to the light, which appears black in the glass, with a finger-width of khaki-cream head that hangs out and leaves a ring of dripping lace. Nose involves dank tropical pineapple, lightly roasted coffee, grapefruit pith and zest, just a menagerie of hop goodness. Lightly sweet, heavily bitter. Medium bodied, active, oily, with a very dry tropical hop finish. Very nice, close to what Sublimely Self-Righteous was if you ever got it within 2-3 weeks old, but more tropical punchy due to the Southern Hemisphere hops.

22 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99 - thanks again, Tom! Enjoy by 01.01.16. Pours a cloudy cocoa brown with a small khaki head that settles into a ring and some spots. Has a hop pellet-like aroma, citrusy and herbal and mildly spicy, with caramel, chocolate, and earth. The flavor is the same, but the hops arent as aggressive. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, bitter mouthfeel that isnt particularly balanced. Still, this worked well for me.

Bottle. Poured dark brown color with an average frothy tan head that lasted and produced excellent lacing. Medium to heavy complex toasted malt, earthy hop and small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a solid beer.

Bomber from Redstone, Andover location. Black thin bubbles of head that stayed around until the last few drops in the glass. Aroma is mild citrus of grapefruit, bold roasted grain and strong pine. 
Honestly, another big, bold slap you in the face IPA from Stone. Make no mistake, this is a huge hop profile. Citrus rind and floral hops start the assault of hops. Grain bill of deep roasted malt tries to balance this but it still is rather off balance. After the citrus and floral notes, pine packs a large pinch in the back end of the sip leading into a lasting pine bitterness. Mild grassy notes after it gets warm. Another bold West Coast IPA that is right in Stones wheelhouse.

22 oz. bottle from Total Wine, Cary, NC (Enjoy By 01-01-16, bottled November 25, 2015). Dark brown cola-like pour with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit rind, pineapple, and fresh pine needles. Bitter piney and citrus hop taste with a smooth chocolatey finish that does not get in the way of the bitterness. A great black IPA.

22 oz bottle shared by Tmoney99. Pours a dark amber brown color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have dank, weedy, light resin, lighter roasted malts that grew with warming, moderate bitterness, leans more toward the ipa side than porter.

Enjoy by 01.01.16, b/o 11.26.15. Deep mahogany pour with impeccable head. Nose of a west coast hop slammer, a myriad of blossoming spruce and citrus fruit, tapered, and more or less framed in a rich caramel and gentle milk chocolate malt. Flavor arrives deeply tropical, is uplifted by heavy floral pine, then grounded by gentle syrupy chocolate malt and some bitter linger. Massive crescendo of flavor brought to a soothing and lasting drone. Hoppy porter-like linger afterward. What is this about it not being too hoppy? Its skillfully balanced. Black IPAs are meant to showcase the malt, too, ya know. Fantastic fantastic fantastic. As is every Enjoy By.

Bottle shared into pint glasses. Appearance: dark blackish reddish brown with a thin khaki colored head that leaves plenty of lacing. Aroma: pine resin, licorice, floral. Taste: mostly resin at first, as the beer warms up it gets more complex - anise, grass, roasted malt, licorice. Palate: great carbonation level, refreshing even though its 9+%.

22oz bottle, from Dutchs. 01.01.16 edition. Great, big tropical fruity resiny hop up front in the aroma. Big huge spicy hop. Just a touch of roast, good big earthiness. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Very dark brown color, slight red. Nearly black. Thin kind of khaki head, leaving great ridges and webs of lace. Bigger bitter taste, lighter sweet. Mild bite on the back end. Long resiny kind of citrusy, spicy hop finish. Really, this is fantastically hoppy. It kind of masks the malt character a bit, hard to really look into it. Its very well blended. Im a fan of balanced black IPAs, but I suppose this one is supposed to be a hop-forward IPA. Its kind of a hop bomb. Maybe it would have been better-balanced closer to new years? But still though, as a hop bomb.. Its great. An exciting, satisfyingly assertive beer.
Draft. Pours deep brown with an off white head. Fruity citric hops, tangerine, moderate bitterness, and some mild roasted malts. Balanced and very drinkable.

Nice sticky khaki head over a dark reddish brown liquid. Explosive hop aroma. Piney aroma with some passion fruit. Just a hint of roast malt. Flavor doesnt live up to the aroma but is still good. Initially roast and slightly metallic. Follows up with tingly resinous hops. Finishes almost watery. Very easy drinking for abv

Bottle.
Black, ruby/brown highlights. Lively tan head. 
Tangerine, minty (strong), guessing a NW hop (like stella) with a bit of anise. Explosive hop nose picked up while pouring. Not on a pale ale side (light, bready) or stout (roast, chocolate). 
Smooooooth. Juicy, tangerine citrus slides down entire palate, with a light resinous after-coat that lingers with a pungent, fresh grapefruit type refreshment burst. Soft upfront, reminiscent of oats/wheat. Way too drinkable for abv strength, alcohol not detectable. 
Hoping for something similiar to a SSR, but this is way different as NW hops are so unique. Very delicious. would drink again.

Draught at Stone Escondido, California. Clear dark amber beer with a nice beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma, tar, citrus, grass, some peach and pine. Hoppy roasted flavor, leather, chocolate, pine, peach, some apricot. Quite nice fruity BIPA.

I dont know really. Its a mystery. A dark mystery.
Just telling a beer buddy that when I cant put my finger 
on a beer, I just give up on it.
Colour is black but light around the edges 
I had to seek this one out, scarce 
Are you going national with the next release 
of this, Stone? If you are, will you tweak it a bit?
I will be a taste taster!
So its not as hoppy forward as reg IPA
1/8th inch head hangs aloof 
Semi licorice, malty something 
Hazy profile Yikes!

Poured from a bottle. Deep brown color, almost black. Beige head. Aroma of citrus and a little cocoa. Bitter pine and grapefruit. Not as good as regular Enjoy By. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Stone World Bistro and Gardens. Pours clear black with a medium, creamy tan head, long retention with light lacing. Aroma is earthy and dank hops and roast malt with light prunes and licorice. Flavor is dank hops, medium bitterness, prunes, earthy notes, roast malt and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Pours near black with a khaki head. Dank hop, citrus, floral, roasted malt and pine aroma. Grapefruit, tangerine, stone fruit, pine, roasty malt, caramel, floral mild cocoa and dank hop flavors. Medium fullish body and average carbonation, Dank hop, grapefruit, pine and slight roasty finish. Very hoppy, its similar to regular Enjoy By with roasted malts. Could be more roasty. Makes me miss Sublimely Self Righteous.

Original version, Enjoy By 11.27.15 Black IPA. Bomber purchased at the brewery in Escondido ($7.25). Pours a medium brown hue (less dark than other Stone versions of this style) with some reddish highlights and one finger of tan head. AROMA of bright tropical fruit, dank-ish hops, pine resin, berries, citrus, but nary a roasty note to be found. FLAVOR of big juicy fruity hops (tropical and stone fruit), tangerine, grapefruit, pine tar...the roasted malt does make itself known here with lesser notes of chocolate and caramel. But the roastiness does not linger...finishes more like a DIPA than a Black IPA with the hops winning big over the malt. Blindfolded, I would never have guessed the color of this beer based on the aroma alone. Despite the coloring, expect lots of big dominating hops in this one. Really good. (4, 984)
22oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Much paler than most black IPAs. Very smooth balance of the hood and malt. Passionfruit aroma and flavor.

Immediate waft of classic enjoy by hops, pines, resin, hop oils and dankness. Thereafter comes deep cocoa, chocolate, toasted nuts, brown sugar, toffee and slight licorice. Pours pitch black with a decent foam head. Taste is heavy bitterness, resin, dankness and hops accompanied by decadent dark malts, toffee, chalky cocoa nibs, dark grain malt and bitter chocolate. Finishes absurdly dry with residual hop oils and resin. Some subtle notes of tangerine, grapefruit juice and orange dance around the palate. Overall, dank, dark and delicious as expected from Stone. The dark components are definitely present but the hops definitely steal the show on this. A rating.

On draft at Stone. Dark chestnut brown pour, near black., with a light tan head. Dank, resinous hops, some tropical fruit, hop juice, bitter, some toffee sweetness, mild roasted barley, and lots of pine. Overall dry, super hoppy, and resinous. If blind tasting this, it would be difficult to tell it was black.
